title: Lars Rönnegård
text:
Statistician and quantitative geneticist.
My research may be described as a combination of data analytics, genetics and ecology. I find the supervision of young researchers truly rewarding and enjoyable. In my spare time I love skiing and walking in the forest.

title: Funded!
text:
A big thank-you to our funding body, the The Nordic Joint Committee for Agricultural and Food Research!
Make sure you have a look at their other fantastic projects and initiatives, and of course stay tuned for more information on our network.

title: Course: Reproducible Research in R
text:
The course will define reproducibility and explain why it is important in scientific practice, publication, and funding. It will introduce basic concepts and tools for ensuring reproducibility in data analysis using R while using public databases for data access and storage. Through presentations, exercises, and discussions participants will learn to increase the reproducibility of their research in the future.
Stay tuned for more information!

title: Amrei Binzer-Panchal
text:
Biologist, bioinformatician and director of SLU’s bioinformatics infrastructure.
I am a biologist turned bioinformatician, who likes programming, puzzle-solving, and teaching. I enjoy fostering connections between people and learning new things. Outside of bioinformatics, I relax with strategic and abstract board games.

title: Kick-off meeting
text:
We will be holding our kick-off meeting on the 22nd of April 2024 online between 12:30 and 16:30. We are currently looking for presenters, as well as people and institutes who would like to join our network!
Please check-in again to get information on exciting topics such as high-throughput phenotyping and “omics” technologies on farms, computational methods and tools, as well as training of up-and-coming agricultural data scientists.

title: Welcome to NADAS
text:
Our aim
Technological advances allowing for cost-effective and high-throughput genetic characterization, and for automated large-scale phenotyping, has brought animal and plant breeding into the so called “big-data” era. Big-data requires special processing pipelines and sophisticated statistical methods and analysis tools than those that have been traditionally employed.
A number of independent projects at the Nordic institutes address these needs individually, but a collective effort at the region-level can help to increase the overall competitiveness, and to ensure the sustainability of Nordic agriculture. These efforts should include also a proper training of agricultural data scientists, which is becoming more evident in today’s data-driven agricultural systems.
We aim at:

exchanging ideas and discussing state-of-the-art approaches for boosting data-driven breeding and farm management in the Nordic region,
promoting sharing of data and analysis tools within the region, and
providing necessary training to young agricultural data scientist to ensure they possess the knowledge needed for securing long-term competitiveness of Nordic farming.

Our network brings together the researchers and PhD students from Aarhus University, Agricultural University of Iceland, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources Institute of Finland, as well as industry stakeholders in the region.


Our funding
We are funded by the The Nordic Joint Committee for Agricultural and Food Research.
